questions.text: Identify the image:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pareto plot

 

The image provided is a Pareto plot.

 

  • Features: The chart presents failure types on the x-axis, the number of occurrences on the left y-axis, and cumulative percentage on the right y-axis. The failures are sorted so that the most frequent problems appear first, with a line tracking their cumulative impact, which is characteristic of a Pareto plot.
  • Purpose: Pareto plots are used to identify and prioritize the most significant factors in a process (the "vital few"), following the 80/20 rule.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Ishikawa chart (also known as fishbone diagram) is used for root cause analysis.

 

Option B. Funnel plot is used in meta-analysis to check for publication bias.

 

Option D. Delphi plot is not a standard statistical plot type. Delphi method is based on the principle that forecasts (or decisions) from a structured group of individuals are more accurate than those from unstructured groups

questions.text: A 34-year-old HIV-positive male presents with lesions on his skin as shown below, along with signs of hepatosplenomegaly. His CD4 count is critically low. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bartonella henselae

 

The most likely organism responsible for these lesions  presenting as multiple red-purple nodules or papules, often with systemic involvement such as hepatosplenomegaly in an HIV-positive patient with low CD4 and hepatosplenomegaly is Bartonella henselae (bacillary angiomatosis).

 

Bacillary angiomatosis in HIV patients is caused by Bartonella henselae (and rarely by B. quintana), Lesions can mimic Kaposi sarcoma but are associated with neutrophilic infiltrates and a positive Warthin–Starry stain for bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bartonella bacilliformis: Causes Oroya fever and Peruvian wart, but not typical in HIV or as bacillary angiomatosis.

 

Option B. HTLV: HTLV is a retrovirus associated with adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma and HTLV-associated myelopathy.

 

Option D. HHV-8: Associated with Kaposi’s sarcoma (can mimic), but lesions are violaceous macules, plaques, or nodules resulting from proliferation of endothelial cells infected with HHV-8.

A virologist is investigating different strains of the Ebola virus. Which strain is recognized as non-pathogenic to humans?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reston

 

  • The Reston ebolavirus is distinguished from other Ebola virus strains by its non-pathogenic nature in humans.
  • Initially identified during an outbreak among monkeys in Virginia, subsequent observations have confirmed that while the Reston strain can infect non-human primates and pigs, it has not caused illness in exposed humans.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zaire: Incorrect. The Zaire strain is highly pathogenic and has the highest mortality rates among the Ebola virus species, responsible for severe outbreaks in humans.


Option C. Cote d’Ivoire: Incorrect. Although it is less virulent than the Zaire strain, the Cote d’Ivoire ebolavirus has been documented to cause human disease.


Option D. Bundibugyo: Incorrect. The Bundibugyo strain has caused significant human mortality during outbreaks, confirming its pathogenicity to humans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among the six known viruses (Zaire, Sudan, Taï Forest, Reston, Bundibugyo and Cote d’Ivoire) within the genus Ebolavirus; Reston virus causes disease in non-human primates. Unlike the other five Ebolaviruses, it is not known to cause disease in humans, but has caused asymptomatic infections.

Identify the disease transmitted by the vector shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zika virus disease

 

The mosquito in the image is Aedes aegypti, also known as the "tiger mosquito" due to the distinctive white stripes on its body and legs. Aedes aegypti is well-known for its "hunchback" posture when feeding and has a flight range of approximately 100 meters, although it may travel farther under certain conditions. This mosquito species primarily breeds in artificial collections of rainwater, such as in discarded tires, bottles, or containers that collect water during the rainy season.

 

Aedes aegypti is the vector responsible for transmitting several viral diseases, including:

 

  • Zika virus disease
  • Dengue fever
  • Chikungunya fever
  • Yellow fever

 

In this case, the correct answer is Zika virus disease, as it is directly associated with this mosquito species.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. JE (Japanese Encephalitis): Japanese Encephalitis is transmitted by the Culex mosquito, specifically Culex tritaeniorhynchus, not by Aedes aegypti.

 

Option C. Malaria: Malaria is transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes, primarily Anopheles gambiae and Anopheles stephensi in different regions, not by Aedes aegypti.

 

Option D. Lymphatic filariasis: Lymphatic filariasis is transmitted by Culex quinquefasciatus (also known as Culex fatigans) in certain regions, rather than by Aedes aegypti.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Aedes aegypti is the vector responsible for transmitting diseases such as Zika virus, dengue, chikungunya, and yellow fever. It is characterized by white stripes on its body and legs and typically breeds in man-made water collections.

questions.text: A hospital administration committee is planning to implement a new protocol for emergency department triage. They wish to involve multiple experts to reach a consensus on the most effective approach. Which of the following methods is most likely to ensure an unbiased, collective agreement among the experts?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Delphi method using structured questionnaires over multiple rounds

 

  • The Delphi method is a systematic, interactive process that uses structured questionnaires to collect input from a group of experts. 
  • It involves multiple rounds, where feedback is aggregated and shared anonymously to reduce bias and encourage consensus. 
  • This is ideal for reaching an agreement on complex topics, such as emergency department triage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focus group discussions with open-ended debates: Focus group discussions may lead to bias due to dominant voices or peer influence, and do not guarantee consensus.

 

Option C. Randomized controlled trials to validate the protocol: Randomized controlled trials are used to validate interventions but are not designed to achieve consensus.

 

Option D. Individual interviews with each expert to finalize the protocol: Individual interviews are useful for gathering opinions but do not facilitate a consensus-building process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Delphi method is an interactive forecasting tool used to achieve consensus among experts through multiple rounds of structured questionnaires.

Under the National Urban Health Mission (NUHM), Urban Social Health Activist (USHA) workers are assigned to cater to a population of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1000–2500

 

  • Urban Social Health Activist (USHA) workers are frontline community health workers designated to serve urban slum populations under the National Urban Health Mission (NUHM). 
  • Each USHA worker is assigned to a population of 1000–2500, or approximately 250–500 households.
  •  Their responsibilities include providing doorstep health services, acting as a link between the Urban Primary Health Centre (UPHC) and the slum community, and promoting health awareness.
  •  USHA workers are typically women aged 25–45 years, residing in the slum, and selected through a community-driven process involving local urban bodies, self-help groups, and Anganwadis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Urban Social Health Activists (USHA) serve as a crucial link between the UPHC and the urban slum population, covering 1000–2500 people (250–500 households), as specified by the NUHM guidelines.

The Stanford Three-Community Study, the North Karelia Project, and the Lipid Research Clinics Study are well-known research efforts. What type of study design best describes these efforts?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Risk factor intervention trials

 

  • These studies are examples of risk factor intervention trials, which involve actively modifying specific risk factors, such as smoking, dietary habits, or cholesterol levels, to observe their effects on health outcomes. 
  • The goal of these trials is to implement and measure the impact of behavioral or clinical interventions in a population, tracking changes in disease incidence based on the modified risk factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cohort studies: Follow participants over time to track outcomes based on exposure, but typically lack a direct intervention component.

 

Option B. Nested case control studies: Select cases and controls within a cohort study but do not actively introduce interventions.

 

Option C. Case series report studies: Describe a series of cases in an observational manner without implementing risk factor modifications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Stanford Three-Community Study, North Karelia Project, and Lipid Research Clinics Study are risk factor intervention trials focused on reducing health risks through targeted interventions, rather than merely observing outcomes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is brought to the ICU after a severe traumatic brain injury following a road traffic accident. He is unresponsive, with no spontaneous movements or brainstem reflexes on examination. Mechanical ventilation is maintaining his respiratory status. A neurologist is consulted to assess for brain death. Which of the following tests is most crucial in confirming the diagnosis of brain death based on Harvard criteria?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presence of apnea during an apnea test after appropriate oxygenation and CO₂ monitoring

 

  • The Harvard criteria for brain death emphasize the importance of apnea testing, which is performed to confirm the absence of spontaneous respiratory effort despite sufficient CO₂ stimulation (typically arterial PaCO₂ >60 mm Hg). 
  • This test, combined with unresponsiveness, absence of brainstem reflexes, and an isoelectric EEG, forms the basis for declaring brain death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Confirmatory MRI showing irreversible damage to the brainstem and cortex: Imaging findings (e.g., MRI) can support the diagnosis of brain injury but are not part of the mandatory confirmatory tests for brain death.

 

Option C. Bilateral absence of pupillary light reflexes without pharmacological influence: Absence of pupillary light reflexes is a brainstem finding but is insufficient alone to confirm brain death; all other criteria must be fulfilled.

 

Option D. Isoelectric EEG recorded for a continuous period of at least 24 hours: An isoelectric EEG supports the diagnosis but does not replace the clinical determination of apnea or brainstem reflex absence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Brain death is a clinical diagnosis that requires unresponsiveness, absence of brainstem reflexes, and apnea confirmed by the apnea test. 
  • Confirmatory tests like EEG provide additional evidence but are not substitutes for clinical evaluation.

questions.text: According to the latest AHA guidelines, what is the sixth link added to the "Chain of Survival"?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Recovery

 

  • The original “Chain of Survival” had 5 links:
    1. Early recognition and call for help (activate EMS)
    2. Early CPR
    3. Rapid defibrillation
    4. Effective advanced life support
    5. Post-cardiac arrest care
  • The latest AHA update adds a 6th link: “Recovery”, emphasizing:
    • Rehabilitation after cardiac arrest
    • Psychological support for survivors and families
    • Community reintegration to improve quality of life

 

Other Option: 

 

Option C. Early discharge: Not part of the official chain; recovery is broader, including rehab and reintegration.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about management of Post-CPR Return of spontaneous circulation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Targeted temperature management at 32 -36° C if patient is awake

 

Targeted Temperature Management (TTM):

 

  • Definition: Controlled reduction of a patient’s core body temperature to 32–36°C after return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) following cardiac arrest.
  • Primary Goal: To minimize neurological injury caused by ischemia-reperfusion and reduce brain edema.
  • Indications:
    • Comatose patients after ROSC (i.e., not following commands).
    • Helps improve survival and neurological outcomes.
  • Contraindications / Not indicated:
    • Patients who are awake, alert, and following commands do not require TTM, as it offers no added benefit and may increase complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MAP > 65 mmHg: Ensures adequate perfusion to vital organs.

 

Option C. SpO₂ 92–98%:  Avoids hypoxia and hyperoxia.

 

Option D. Emergent cardiac intervention if STEMI present: PCI or reperfusion is indicated.

questions.text: Researchers at an academic trauma center conducted a randomized clinical trial comparing 2 surgical techniques (Technique A and Technique B) for repairing a mandible fracture. They examined rates of infectious complications and rates of malocclusion. A total of 100 patients were enrolled in the study. Results showed that the relative rate of infection with Technique A compared with Technique B was 0.86 with a 95% confidence interval of 0.57-1.28. What is a correct statement?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neither surgery technique is superior

 

Since the confidence interval (0.57–1.28) includes 1, there is no statistically significant difference between the two techniques. Hence, neither can be considered superior in terms of reducing infection or complications, and both remain acceptable for use in clinical care.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presented with pain and tightness on the glans penis and pigmentation with difficulty in urination. Examination finding is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Balanitis xerotica

 

The image depicts white, atrophic, sclerotic patches affecting the glans penis with ulceration and difficulty in retracting the foreskin, suggestive of balanitis xerotica obliterans (also termed lichen sclerosus), a chronic inflammatory condition causing pain, tightening, and urinary symptoms.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Condyloma acuminata: Presents as exophytic, warty lesions due to HPV infection, usually not ulcerative or sclerotic.


Option C. Erythroplasia of Queyrat (EQ): Appears as a red, velvety plaque on the glans, not as white sclerosed tissue.


Option D. Peyronie’s disease: Characterized by fibrous plaques in the tunica albuginea causing penile curvature, not cutaneous or mucosal lesions.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by his friends after being found unconscious. His friends report that he had been using heroin earlier in the day. On examination, the patient is unresponsive, his respiratory rate is 6 breaths per minute, pupils are pinpoint, and his oxygen saturation is 85% on room air. What is the most appropriate immediate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Administer intravenous naloxone

 

  • The patient presents with symptoms of opioid overdose, characterized by unresponsiveness, respiratory depression (respiratory rate of 6 breaths/min), pinpoint pupils, and low oxygen saturation (85%). 
  • The most appropriate immediate management is the administration of naloxone, an opioid receptor antagonist that rapidly reverses opioid-induced respiratory depression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation: While intubation may be required in severe cases where naloxone is ineffective, it is not the initial management. Naloxone should be administered first, as it can rapidly improve respiratory effort and prevent the need for intubation.

 

 Option C. Start intravenous fluids and observe: IV fluids do not address the respiratory depression caused by opioid overdose and are not the primary treatment in this case.

 

Option D. Provide oxygen via nasal cannula and monitor: While supplemental oxygen is important to correct hypoxemia, it does not address the underlying cause (opioid-induced respiratory depression). Naloxone remains the priority intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The opioids are lethal in overdose.

 

 

The drug of choice for treatment of opioid overdose is i.v. naloxone (short-acting opioid antagonist).

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presented with a great toe infection. She had a significant discoloration with a subungual hyperkeratosis that caused surface changes. She was suspected of having onychomycosis. Which is the topical drug given in toenail onychomycosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tavaborole

 

Onychomycosis is a fungal infection of the nails, commonly caused by dermatophytes (e.g., Trichophyton rubrum), and presents with nail discoloration, subungual hyperkeratosis, and nail plate deformity. Tavaborole is a topical antifungal agent (oxaborole class) that inhibits fungal protein synthesis by blocking leucyl-tRNA synthetase. It is FDA-approved for topical treatment of toenail onychomycosis and is applied daily for 48 weeks. Tavaborole is particularly useful for mild to moderate cases or when systemic therapy is contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Itraconazole: An oral triazole antifungal used in the treatment of systemic mycoses and onychomycosis. It works by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis. Oral itraconazole is effective for toenail disease and is used in pulse or continuous regimens.

 

Option C. Griseofulvin: An older oral antifungal that inhibits fungal mitosis by disrupting microtubule function. It was historically used for dermatophyte infections of skin, hair, and nails but is now largely replaced by terbinafine and itraconazole due to lower efficacy and longer treatment duration. Not given topically for nails.

 

Option D. Caspofungin: An echinocandin antifungal that inhibits β-glucan synthesis in the fungal cell wall. It is used intravenously for serious systemic infections such as invasive candidiasis and aspergillosis.

A 4-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a 3-day history of fever, painful oral ulcers, and a rash affecting the hands and feet. The mother also reports that the child’s nails have started to peel off or appear abnormal in the past few days. What is the most likely nail finding associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Onychomadesis

 

  • The clinical presentation of fever, oral ulcers, and a rash on the hands and feet strongly suggests Hand-Foot-Mouth Disease (HFMD), a common viral illness caused by enteroviruses, particularly Coxsackievirus A16 and Enterovirus 71.
    • A characteristic nail finding associated with HFMD is onychomadesis, which is the painless, spontaneous separation of the nail from the nail matrix, leading to nail shedding.
    • The exact mechanism of onychomadesis in HFMD is unclear but is thought to result from temporary arrest in nail matrix activity due to systemic illness or viral invasion.
    • This finding typically occurs 1–2 weeks after the onset of HFMD and resolves without specific treatment as the nails regrow.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pterygium: Pterygium refers to scarring of the nail fold leading to adhesion between the nail bed and the proximal nail fold, typically seen in autoimmune diseases like lichen planus. It is not associated with HFMD.

 

Option C. Onycholysis: Onycholysis is the detachment of the nail plate from the nail bed, commonly seen in conditions like psoriasis, fungal infections, or trauma. It is distinct from onychomadesis and not associated with HFMD.

 

Option D. Clubbing: Clubbing is the bulbous enlargement of the distal fingers and nails, seen in chronic hypoxic conditions (e.g., congenital heart disease, pulmonary diseases) and does not occur in HFMD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Onychomadesis (painless nail shedding) is a recognized nail finding associated with Hand-Foot-Mouth Disease (HFMD), typically occurring 1–2 weeks after the onset of symptoms and resolving spontaneously.

questions.text: A 30-year-old individual presents with multiple blistering skin lesions. A skin biopsy reveals acantholysis, characterized by the loss of adhesion between keratinocytes. Which of the following conditions is least likely to display acantholytic cells on histological examination?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection

 

  • Acantholysis refers to the separation and loss of adhesion between keratinocytes within the epidermis, leading to the formation of distinct "acantholytic cells." This histological feature is a hallmark of several dermatological conditions. 
  • In the context of the presented case, the presence of acantholysis suggests a disorder that disrupts keratinocyte connections. 
  • Pemphigus, herpes simplex infection, and bullous impetigo are all associated with such disruptions, resulting in acantholytic cells. 
  • However, Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection is characterized by a different cytopathic effect known as koilocytic change. 
  • This involves perinuclear halos and nuclear atypia in keratinocytes, which are distinct from the acantholytic changes observed in other conditions. 
  • Therefore, HPV infection does not typically exhibit acantholysis and is least likely to present with acantholytic cells on histological examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus: Pemphigus is an autoimmune blistering disorder where autoantibodies target Desmogleins, components of desmosomes that facilitate keratinocyte adhesion. This disruption leads to prominent acantholysis and intraepidermal blister formation.

 

Option C. Herpes simplex infection: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection causes ballooning degeneration of keratinocytes, leading to vesicle formation accompanied by acantholysis. Histology may also reveal multinucleated giant cells and viral inclusions.

 

Option D. Bullous impetigo: Bullous impetigo, often caused by Staphylococcus aureus producing exfoliative toxins, leads to the cleavage within the epidermis and acantholysis, resulting in blister formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acantholysis, the loss of keratinocyte adhesion, is observed in conditions such as pemphigus, herpes simplex infection, and bullous impetigo, but not typically in Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, which instead causes koilocytic changes.

questions.text: A 3-minute-old newborn is being resuscitated due to signs of respiratory distress. Where should the clinical team place the pulse oximeter to measure oxygen saturation in this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right upper limb

 

  • In newborn resuscitation, pre-ductal SpO₂ is preferred because it reflects oxygenation before blood mixes through the ductus arteriosus.
  • Right upper limb (typically right hand) is considered pre-ductal, while lower limbs reflect post-ductal oxygen saturation.
  • Importance:
    • Pre-ductal saturation guides initial oxygen therapy in newborns.
    • Post-ductal readings may be lower due to right-to-left shunting across the ductus arteriosus, giving underestimation of arterial oxygenation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left upper limb: Can be pre-ductal, but right upper limb is standard for consistency.

 

Option B. Left lower limb: Post-ductal; may underestimate true systemic oxygenation.

 

Option D. Right lower limb: Post-ductal; less reliable for initial resuscitation guidance.

A 45-year-old male is scheduled for elective hernia repair surgery. His preoperative assessment shows normal liver function, but he has a history of moderate asthma, for which he uses an inhaler intermittently. Which inhalational agent is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sevoflurane

 

Sevoflurane is the preferred inhalational agent in patients with reactive airway disease (asthma) because it:

 

  • Has bronchodilator properties, reducing the risk of bronchospasm.
  • Is non-pungent and less irritating to the airways, making induction smooth.
  • Has rapid onset and recovery, which is ideal for elective procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Desflurane: Pungent and can irritate the airways, triggering bronchospasm in asthmatic patients; less suitable for induction.

 

Option C. Halothane: Historically used, but hepatotoxicity risk limits its use; slower onset than sevoflurane.

 

Option D. Nitrous oxide: Not irritating, but weak bronchodilator; usually used as an adjunct, not primary agent for asthmatic patients. Nitrous oxide is the least potent inhalational anesthetic

A drug classified as an inverse agonist at benzodiazepine receptors is likely to produce which of the following effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased anxiety and seizures

 

  • Inverse agonists at benzodiazepine receptors, such as beta-carbolines, reduce receptor activity below baseline, opposing the effects of benzodiazepine agonists. 
  • This leads to increased neuronal excitability, manifesting as heightened anxiety, restlessness, and seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sedation and anxiolysis: Sedation and anxiolysis are effects of agonists at benzodiazepine receptors, not inverse agonists.

 

Option C. Reduction of dopamine activity: Dopamine activity is not directly affected by benzodiazepine receptor modulation.

 

Option D. Partial dopamine receptor blockade: Partial dopamine receptor blockade is unrelated to benzodiazepine receptor effects.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Inverse agonists reduce receptor activity below baseline, leading to excitatory effects like anxiety and seizures at benzodiazepine receptors.

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient presents with monkeypox and is started on tecovirimat for treatment. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of tecovirimat?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Targets the viral p37 protein, preventing viral envelopment and systemic spread.

 

  • Tecovirimat is an antiviral medication that targets the orthopoxvirus p37 protein, which is necessary for the virus's envelopment. 
  • By inhibiting this protein, tecovirimat prevents the formation of extracellular viral particles, which are responsible for the systemic spread of the infection. 
  • It does not affect the intracellular forms of the virus, which are responsible for replication inside the cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibits the formation of intracellular viral forms of orthopoxviruses: This is incorrect. Tecovirimat does not affect the intracellular forms of the virus but targets the viral p37 protein involved in the formation of extracellular forms.

 

Option C. Suppresses the replication of the variola virus within the host cell: This is incorrect. Tecovirimat does not directly inhibit viral replication; instead, it prevents the production of extracellular viral particles by targeting the p37 protein.

 

Option D. Inhibits viral entry into host cells by blocking the viral fusion protein: This is incorrect. Tecovirimat does not block viral entry. It works by preventing the envelopment of the virus, thus halting the release of infectious viral particles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tecovirimat targets the orthopoxvirus p37 protein, inhibiting the envelopment of the virus and preventing the release of extracellular viral particles responsible for the systemic spread of the infection.

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient presents with multiple soft, pedunculated skin lesions on the trunk. On palpation, these lesions are compressible and invaginate into the skin upon gentle pressure, creating a characteristic "button-hole" appearance. This finding is most commonly associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neurofibromatosis type 1

 

  • The "button-hole sign" refers to a clinical observation where skin lesions, typically neurofibromas, are compressible and can be invaginated into the skin upon gentle pressure. 
  • This sign is a characteristic feature of von Recklinghausen’s disease (Neurofibromatosis type 1). 
  • Neurofibromas are benign nerve sheath tumors that develop in this genetic disorder, which is caused by mutations in the NF1 gene. 
  • The button-hole sign is considered pathognomonic for neurofibromas and is a key finding in diagnosing Neurofibromatosis type 1.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): SLE is an autoimmune disorder that affects multiple organs and may present with skin manifestations such as a malar rash or photosensitivity. However, it does not exhibit the button-hole sign, as neurofibromas are not a feature of SLE.

 

Option B. Discoid lupus erythematosus: Discoid lupus erythematosus is a cutaneous manifestation of lupus characterized by chronic scarring lesions and depigmentation. These lesions are not compressible and do not exhibit the button-hole sign. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

 

Option D. Psoriasis: Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory condition presenting with erythematous plaques covered with silvery scales. It does not involve neurofibromas or display the button-hole sign, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The button-hole sign, where lesions are compressible and invaginate into the skin upon pressure, is a characteristic clinical finding in neurofibromas. 
  • This is a hallmark feature of Neurofibromatosis type 1 (von Recklinghausen’s disease), a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the NF1 gene.

questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radial

 

Radial artery is the most commonly used site for invasive arterial pressure monitoring because:

 

  1. Easily accessible and superficial.
  2. Allows continuous beat-to-beat BP monitoring.
  3. Low risk of complications.
  4. Collateral circulation is usually confirmed by Allen’s test, reducing risk of ischemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulnar: Usually not used as the primary site; smaller and deeper, harder to cannulate.

 

Option C. Brachial: Larger artery, more central, but higher risk of limb ischemia if thrombosis occurs; rarely first choice.

 

Option D. Femoral: Used when upper limb access not feasible, or for very high-risk cardiac patients, but higher infection and hematoma risk.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of the triad of poikiloderma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Skin hypertrophy

 

The triad of poikiloderma includes:

 

  1. Skin atrophy: Thinning and weakening of the skin.
  2. Telangiectasia: Dilated superficial blood vessels visible on the skin.
  3. Pigmentary changes: A mottled appearance due to hyperpigmentation and hypopigmentation.

 

Skin hypertrophy (thickening of the skin) is not part of the triad and represents a distinct pathological process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The triad of poikiloderma consists of skin atrophy, telangiectasia, and pigmentary changes. Skin hypertrophy is not part of this triad and suggests a different dermatological or systemic condition. 
  • This pattern is often seen in mycosis fungoides and other chronic dermatoses.

questions.text: Which of the following interventions would be most effective in helping a country escape a demographic trap?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Promoting the use of contraception and family planning

 

  • Demographic trap: Applies to a country whose population is growing rapidly due to a high birth rate and low death rate. 
  • To escape the demographic trap, countries need to lower fertility rates. 
  • Promoting family planning and contraception reduces birth rates, helping to stabilize population growth and reduce pressure on resources.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increasing the availability of advanced medical care: This reduces death rates further but does not address high fertility rates.

 

Option C. Improving economic opportunities in rural areas: This may have an indirect effect but does not directly address high fertility.

 

Option D. Expanding immunization coverage for childhood diseases: This primarily reduces child mortality and death rates, exacerbating the demographic trap if fertility rates remain high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Promoting family planning and contraception is the most effective intervention to escape the demographic trap by reducing high fertility rates.

questions.text: A pharmaceutical company conducts a cross-over study to compare the efficacy of two antihypertensive medications, Drug X and Drug Y. Participants receive Drug X for 4 weeks, undergo a 2-week washout period, and then receive Drug Y for 4 weeks. Upon analyzing the data, researchers observe that blood pressure measurements during the Drug Y phase are significantly lower than during the Drug X phase. However, they also note a progressive decrease in blood pressure readings over the entire study duration, irrespective of the treatment administered. Which of the following phenomena is most likely responsible for this observation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Period effect

 

  • A period effect refers to changes in the outcome variable that occur due to the passage of time rather than the specific treatments administered.
  • In this scenario, the progressive decrease in blood pressure over time, regardless of whether the participant is receiving Drug X or Drug Y, suggests a period effect.
  • This could be due to factors such as lifestyle modifications, increased adherence to study protocols, or other time-related influences that affect blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carryover effect: This occurs when the effects of the first treatment persist into the period when the second treatment is administered. The presence of a washout period is intended to minimize this effect. In this case, the consistent decline over time does not align with a carryover effect.

 

Option C. Regression to the mean: This statistical phenomenon occurs when extreme measurements tend to move closer to the average upon subsequent testing. It does not adequately explain a continuous downward trend over the study period.

 

Option D. Sequence effect: This refers to differences in outcomes depending on the order in which treatments are administered. The observed trend is independent of treatment sequence, making this explanation less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cross-over studies, period effects can influence outcomes independently of the treatments being tested. Researchers must account for these effects to ensure accurate interpretation of results.

Match the following nail appearances: 

 

  1. Arsenic poisoning
  2. Lymphedema
  3. Renal failure 
  4. Malnourishment 

 

a) Muerhke’s lines

b) Mees lines

c) Yellow nail

d) Leukonychia
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

1. Arsenic poisoning → Mees lines (b): Transverse white lines across the nail plate that move with nail growth, typically appearing after arsenic or other heavy metal exposure. They indicate acute systemic insult.

 

2. Lymphedema → Yellow nails (c): Nails appear thickened, slow-growing, and yellow due to lymphatic stasis. Often associated with chronic lymphedema, impaired nail growth, and secondary infections.

 

3. Renal failure → Leukonychia (d): Diffuse whitening of the nail plate, sometimes with ground-glass appearance, caused by protein abnormalities and metabolic changes seen in chronic renal disease.

 

4. Malnourishment → Muehrcke’s lines (a): Paired transverse white bands that do not move with nail growth, representing hypoalbuminemia, commonly observed in protein-calorie malnutrition or liver disease.

A 36-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a 4-day history of fever and painful vesicular lesions around her lips, as shown in the image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cold sore

 

  • The lesion’s location around the lips, its vesicular appearance, and the associated fever are characteristic of cold sores.
  • Cold sores, or herpes labialis, are caused by the herpes simplex virus (typically HSV-1). 
  • They often present with painful, vesicular lesions around the mouth and are associated with systemic symptoms like fever, particularly during primary infection or reactivation. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hand, foot, and mouth disease: This disease typically presents with vesicular lesions on the hands, feet, and inside the mouth but not specifically around the lips. It is usually caused by the coxsackievirus, and lesions around the lips alone are uncommon.

 

Option B. Warts: Warts are caused by the human papillomavirus and typically appear as firm, rough papules rather than vesicular lesions. They are not associated with fever.

 

Option C. Herpes zoster: Herpes zoster (shingles) can cause vesicular lesions but is typically seen in a dermatomal distribution, often on the trunk or face but not limited to the lip area. It also occurs more commonly in older adults and is associated with a history of varicella (chickenpox) infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cold sores (herpes labialis) present with painful vesicular lesions around the mouth, often triggered by HSV-1, and can be associated with fever during reactivation.

questions.text: Given that the Total Fertility Rate (TFR) in India is 2.2, which of the following is the most likely estimate for the Crude Birth Rate (CBR)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 18.6 per 1000 population

 

  • The Crude Birth Rate (CBR) can be roughly estimated using the following relationship with the Total Fertility Rate (TFR):

 

CBR ≈ ( 8 × TFR ) + 1

 

  • In this case, the Total Fertility Rate (TFR) is given as 2.2. Using the formula:

 

CBR = (8×2.2) + 1 = 17.6 + 1 = 18.6 per 1000 population

 

  • Therefore, the most accurate estimate for the Crude Birth Rate (CBR) in India with a TFR of 2.2 is 18.6 per 1000 population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To estimate the Crude Birth Rate (CBR) from the Total Fertility Rate (TFR), use the formula:

 

CBR ≈ (8×TFR) + 1

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presents for vaccination, and the physician discusses options for rotavirus vaccines. Which of the following is a true statement regarding Rotarix and Rotavac vaccines?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rotarix is a live attenuated monovalent vaccine targeting serotype G1P[8].

 

  • Rotarix is a monovalent live attenuated vaccine targeting serotype G1P[8], administered orally in a two-dose schedule. 
  • Rotavac is also a live attenuated vaccine but targets serotype G9P[11]. Rotavac is monovalent, not pentavalent. 
  • Both vaccines are administered orally, not intramuscularly. Rotarix follows a two-dose schedule, while Rotavac may follow a two- or three-dose schedule.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rotavac is a pentavalent vaccine targeting multiple serotypes of rotavirus: Incorrect, as Rotavac is monovalent, not pentavalent.

 

Option C. Both vaccines are subunit vaccines and administered intramuscularly: Incorrect, as both vaccines are live attenuated and administered orally, not subunit or intramuscular vaccines.

 

Option D. Rotarix requires a three-dose schedule as per the National Immunization Schedule: Incorrect, as Rotarix follows a two-dose schedule, not three-dose.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A male patient presents with a history of foot trauma followed by a left toenail infection. He is diagnosed with onychomycosis and shows improvement after treatment with terbinafine. Which part of the nail is primarily affected by this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nail plate

 

  • Tinea unguium, or onychomycosis, primarily affects the nail plate, resulting in thickening, discoloration, and potential nail dystrophy. 
  • The condition is commonly caused by dermatophytes and can be effectively treated with antifungal agents like terbinafine.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nail bed: The nail bed lies underneath the nail plate, and while it may be secondarily affected, it is not the primary target in onychomycosis.

 

Option B. Nail fold: The nail fold may be involved in other types of nail infections, such as paronychia, but is not the main site in Tinea unguium.

 

Option D. Cuticle: The cuticle is the skin at the base of the nail and is not typically involved in onychomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Onychomycosis (Tinea unguium) primarily affects the nail plate, leading to nail thickening, discoloration, and dystrophy. 
  • Treatment typically involves antifungal medications such as terbinafine.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male soldier presents for a routine examination. He has been on combination antiretroviral therapy (CART) for the past 2 weeks and expresses a desire to discontinue his HIV treatment. He complains of dizziness and strange nightmares that began after starting the therapy. Which of the following medications is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Efavirenz

 

  • Efavirenz, a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI), is well-known for causing central nervous system (CNS) side effects, which include:
    1. Dizziness
    2. Vivid dreams or nightmares
    3. Sleep disturbances
    4. Impaired concentration
  • These symptoms typically occur within the first few weeks of therapy and may resolve over time in some patients. Efavirenz is unique among antiretrovirals for its neuropsychiatric effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dolutegravir: Dolutegravir, an integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI), is generally well-tolerated but may occasionally cause insomnia or mild headaches, not vivid dreams or nightmares.

 

Option B. Lamivudine: Lamivudine, a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI), is well-tolerated and not associated with CNS side effects like dizziness or nightmares.

 

Option C. Tenofovir: Tenofovir, another NRTI, can cause renal toxicity or reduced bone mineral density but does not typically cause CNS side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize Efavirenz as the antiretroviral agent most associated with CNS side effects, including vivid dreams and dizziness.
  • Understand that CNS symptoms are most prominent during the initial weeks of therapy and may resolve over time.
  • Emphasize the importance of counseling patients regarding potential side effects to improve medication adherence.

questions.text: A 4-month-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parents for a well-child check. She was evaluated 2 weeks ago for a rash in the diaper area. At that visit, the patient was found to have erythematous papules in the diaper area that spared the skin folds. Her symptoms improved with use of a petrolatum barrier ointment with every diaper change. Today, vital signs and physical examination are normal. Which of the following most likely contributed to this patient's prior skin findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Altered local skin pH

 

This infant had erythematous papules in the diaper area that spared skin folds, which improved with petrolatum barrier ointment—classic features of irritant diaper dermatitis. The main contributing factor is prolonged exposure to urine and feces, which raises the local skin pH, disrupting the acidic skin barrier and making the epidermis more susceptible to irritation. The elevated pH activates fecal enzymes (lipases and proteases) that break down the stratum corneum, leading to inflammation and erythema. Management includes frequent diaper changes, barrier creams, and maintaining proper hygiene to restore skin pH and prevent recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abnormal keratin expression: Disorders like ichthyosis or keratinopathic epidermal disorders involve defective keratin production, causing scaling and barrier defects. These are genetic and chronic, rather than acute, and usually present with diffuse scaling.

 

Option C. Increased hapten sensitization: This occurs in allergic contact dermatitis, where small molecules (haptens) trigger an immune response. Allergic rashes often involve skin folds, have vesicles, and may recur with repeated exposure to the allergen.

 

Option D. Local bacterial colonization: Bacterial overgrowth (eg, Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus) can exacerbate diaper dermatitis, causing pustules or oozing. However, simple irritant diaper rash is primarily non-infectious, and secondary infection occurs only if the barrier is broken or the inflammation persists.

questions.text: A study calculated the correlation coefficient between smoking and lung cancer incidence as 1.4. What does this result indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mistake in calculation

 

  • The correlation coefficient (r) ranges from -1 to +1, where +1 indicates a perfect positive correlation, -1 indicates a perfect negative correlation, and 0 indicates no correlation. 
  • A value of 1.4 is outside this range, meaning an error must have occurred in the calculation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Correlation coefficients must fall between -1 and +1. A value outside this range, such as 1.4, suggests a calculation error.

questions.text: A study is conducted to investigate the relationship between smoking and lung cancer. The findings suggest that the association between smoking and lung cancer is stronger in individuals who exercise less and weaker in individuals who exercise more. In this case, exercise is considered:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Effect modifier

 

  • An effect modifier (also called an interaction factor) is a variable that modifies the strength or direction of the association between the primary exposure (in this case, smoking) and the outcome (lung cancer). 
  • In this study, the relationship between smoking and lung cancer is different depending on the level of exercise. 
  • The effect of smoking on lung cancer is stronger in people who exercise less and weaker in those who exercise more, indicating that exercise modifies the effect of smoking on the likelihood of developing lung cancer. 
  • This makes exercise an effect modifier.
  • Effect modification is important because it highlights that the association between an exposure and an outcome may vary across different subgroups or levels of another variable, like exercise in this case. 
  • The effect modifier can alter the magnitude or direction of the exposure-outcome relationship.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bias: Bias refers to systematic errors in the design, conduct, or analysis of a study that leads to incorrect conclusions. While bias can affect the validity of a study, it is not the same as an effect modifier. Bias would distort the observed relationship, but it wouldn't explain why the effect varies with exercise.

 

Option C. Confounding factor: A confounding factor is a variable that is associated with both the exposure and the outcome and can lead to a distorted or misleading estimate of the relationship between them. Confounders are typically distributed unequally between the study groups, leading to a false association or masking the true association. In this case, exercise is not confounding the relationship between smoking and lung cancer but is actually modifying the relationship.

 

Option D. Collinear factor: Collinearity refers to the situation where two independent variables are highly correlated with each other, making it difficult to distinguish their individual effects on the outcome. While air pollution and urban area residence may exhibit collinearity in studies of lung cancer, exercise and smoking in this study are not collinear. Rather, exercise is influencing the strength of the relationship between smoking and lung cancer, not simply being highly correlated with smoking.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • An effect modifier is a variable that alters the strength or direction of the association between an exposure (like smoking) and an outcome (like lung cancer). 
  • In studies, an effect modifier can highlight how the relationship between the primary exposure and outcome differs across levels or subgroups of the modifier.

questions.text: A 45-year-old gardener presents to the clinic with a 2-week history of painless nodular lesions on his left forearm. He recalls pricking his hand on a thorn while trimming rose bushes 3 weeks ago. The lesions began as a small papule on his hand and have since spread proximally along the forearm in a linear pattern. He denies fever, chills, or systemic symptoms. The image of the lesion is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Itraconazole

 

  • The patient’s history of gardening, traumatic inoculation, and the presence of painless nodular lesions following a lymphatic distribution is characteristic of sporotrichosis, caused by Sporothrix schenckii. 
  • Itraconazole, an oral antifungal, is the treatment of choice for cutaneous and lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline: Doxycycline is effective against bacterial infections and some rickettsial diseases but is not effective for fungal infections like sporotrichosis.

 

Option C. Amphotericin B: Amphotericin B is reserved for severe systemic fungal infections, such as disseminated sporotrichosis, but is not necessary for localized lymphocutaneous cases.

 

Option D. Flucloxacillin: Flucloxacillin is an antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections like cellulitis or abscesses caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It is not effective against fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sporotrichosis is a subcutaneous fungal infection often associated with traumatic inoculation during gardening. 
  • The typical presentation includes nodular lesions spreading along lymphatics, and itraconazole is the first-line treatment for lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old HIV-positive child with a CD4 count of 320 cells/mm³ and WHO stage 3 clinical status has been initiated on cotrimoxazole prophylaxis. When should prophylaxis be discontinued in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) When the CD4 count exceeds 350 cells/mm³, and the child has been on ART for at least 6 months.

 

  • For children older than 5 years, discontinuation of cotrimoxazole prophylaxis is recommended when their CD4 count exceeds 350 cells/mm³ and they have been stable on ART for at least 6 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. When the child reaches 10 years of age, irrespective of ART adherence: Age is not the sole criterion; CD4 count and ART duration are more critical.

 

Option C. Cotrimoxazole prophylaxis should continue indefinitely for all HIV-positive children: Discontinuation is possible under specific conditions, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Discontinuation should occur only when the child demonstrates undetectable viral loads for over 12 months: Viral load monitoring is essential but not the only criterion for discontinuation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cotrimoxazole prophylaxis in HIV-positive children older than 5 years can be discontinued when the CD4 count is >350 cells/mm³, and ART has been effective for at least 6 months.

questions.text: A public health campaign increases vaccination rates against HPV 16 and 18. Increased vaccination rates would have which of the following effects on the Papanicolaou test?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Decreased positive predictive value

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with metastatic lung cancer is enrolled in a clinical trial comparing the effectiveness of two new chemotherapy regimens on overall survival. The study monitors patients for five years, and survival data is presented using Kaplan-Meier curves. Which statistical test is most appropriate to determine if there is a significant difference in survival between the two groups?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cox proportional hazards model

 

  • The Cox proportional hazards model is used in survival analysis to compare time-to-event data between two or more groups while adjusting for covariates. 
  • It evaluates the hazard ratio, providing insight into the relative risk of an event occurring in one group compared to another. 
  • Kaplan-Meier curves visually represent the survival function, and the Cox model complements this by providing statistical significance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Logistic regression: Logistic regression is used for binary outcomes, not time-to-event data.

 

Option B. Chi-square test: The chi-square test is used for categorical data and is not appropriate for analyzing survival data.

 

Option C. ANOVA: ANOVA compares means between groups, but it does not handle survival or time-to-event data.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • The Cox proportional hazards model is used in survival analysis to compare the hazard rates between groups while accounting for covariates.
